This isn't against this channel personally, just saying that for me at least and a lot of people i know these science videos on youtube it would be so much easier to process and understand without all the jokes. It's just so much being thrown at you for a viewer, all this information you're trying to make sense of and you have to quickly realize what's important information and what's a joke. The jokes are distracting, and for me and i'm sure a lot of people, annoying-even if it was a good joke, because it distracts from the information and you have to try and think about the concept from the beginning all over again. For me i have to replay things multiple times a lot of the time to go back to try and connect the relevant concepts. I get why the jokes are there, cause creators think it would be boring without them, but a lot of people would prefer it that way- i wish there was at least one channel that had the helpful animatics and that was all it was. If i had the time i would love to make a channel where i take science videos and edit out the jokes so it's just the useful explanation and that's it, they don't try to make it 'comedy'.

Intergalactic Subculture Sweets+ Yes, but the capacity to manipulate a cell is a sign of life. Viruses are at the very edge of life, they can do something only inside a cell, so, this is a quality that give them a place in the group of the living things. They aren't like all of the life form on this planet, maybe they are the missing ring between macromolecules and the simplest life form (bacteria).

Biology is a bunch of assumptions. The earth is alive and its not a globe!

So they aren't alive because they lack properties of living things. They do not have any form of metabolism; they don't grow, they produce no waste, they do not respond to stimuli. They also cannot reproduce, but, instead infect an actually living cell which then turns that infected cell into a sort of 'virus factory'. That cell then creates viruses for that virus and this can happen more than one way. Regardless to that, they are not alive because they lack the properties that can classify it as alive. This was explained to me by my wife, soon to be med student, who has a much better understanding of this than me. I hope this helps.

Great question! Yes, actually Human beings are capable of using certain cells from other organisms. A lot of species can use certain cells and structures from other species- however, there are many limitations because of differences in blood type, cellular structure, enzyme functionality, and molecular components. But, it is possible.  (The next two things don't answer your question, but I thought, eh, they're cool enough to be worthy of saying)  It's also possible for animals to use parts from certain organ systems in other organ systems. Dogs, for example, have had parts of their intestinal tract cut and used them to replace a part of their esophagus (a large portion), and within several days the intestinal-esophagus worked as well as the original, and within a few weeks you couldn't tell the implanted esophagus from the first one.  There is a very popular hypothesis in biology that mitochondria, the energy producers of the cell, were once their own separate prokaryotic cell that was 'consumed', per say, in another prokaryotic cell. And this would have to have happened very early on in the history of life because nearly all cells have mitochondria, and the structure of mitochondria seem to indicate an ability to have once survived on their own.  So, for sci-fi stuff, there are two more ideas you can use somehow, I'm sure! :D

Most likely, yes. But tampering with an ecosystem by removing such a hugely significant group of organisms is generally a terrible idea.  By hugely significant, I mean that there are *a lot* of mosquitoes. They constitute a large part of the food web. If we remove them, the food web will restructure itself, but we have no idea what kind of secondary effects that would have. Baby mosquitoes are a component of freshwater systems; adult males feed on plants. Shit's complicated, yo.

"Purpose" is not a term that any ecologist would use. Also, it's wrong to assume that only specialists are affected by the extinction of other species.  There may be few creatures that eat *only* mosquitoes, but lots of things include them in their diet. They may adapt without mosquitoes, but the food web would change. Also, nothing eats lions, but that doesn't mean removing lions wouldn't affect the system - top-down control is a thing, too.
Yeah, no. It's part temperate deciduous forest, part temperate rainforest. But he didn't include temperate rainforest into this rather simplified classification scheme.

Not everything that *affects* the biosphere is *part* of the biosphere. Cosmic radiation from the stars affects living things too, but we can't count them into the biosphere.  Mostly when we talk about the biosphere we mean the sum total of all living things. If you extend the term you get the geobiosphere, which also includes all the material (minerals; atmosphere; water) that gets processed through and affected by living things.
